questions.question_text:
A network administrator installed a web server on a Linux host and added a firewalld command to open port 80/tcp. The web server worked without error until an updated and patched kernel was installed on the system a month later. Now users are unable to access the web server even though the service is running.
Which of the following would fix the issue?

choices.B: Change the firewalld zone to private and open port tcp/80
choices.D: Use the firewalld command to open tcp/80 both with and without the --permanent switch
choices.C: Issue an additional firewalld command to open up port tcp/443 as well as port tcp/80
choices.A: Use the firewalld command to open the HTTP application service rather than the port

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D:
I have used firewalld commands before, if you don't run the command a 2nd time with the --permanent flag the entry is removed on reboot and/or restart of Firewalld.

I hope it should be D.
In firewalld, rules can be designated as either permanent or immediate. If a rule is added or modified, by default, the behavior of the currently running firewall is modified. At the next boot, the modifications will be thrown out and the old rules will be applied.
There is no private zone in firewalld also, so the answer does not make sense. Also, it is very tricky.

Selected Answer: C
It should be C

Selected Answer: D
D is correct.
-qi (query information)
https://phoenixnap.com/kb/rpm-command-in-linux

I assume proper command should be "rpm -qpi file.rpm"
w/o --info we will not get details. but w/o --package we cannot read info from rpm file. Looks like B is the most suitable, but in my opinion each command is bad.

Selected Answer: B
Answer is B since "-i" would install the package.
-i, --install Install package(s).
-q, --query Query package(s).

Selected Answer: B
rpm -qp
-q query
-p package

questions.question_text:
A junior administrator needs to display information for an RPM package that contains software from an external provider.
Which of the following commands will display the package information?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C:
After creating a partition with fdisk, you cannot add a file system to that partition unless the kernel can read it from the partition table. You might receive an error like"Re-reading the partition table failed" during the fdisk operation. Rebooting the machine updates the table, or you can issue partprobe instead to update the table without a reboot.

questions.question_text:
A storage administrator added a new primary partition to a drive and wants to create a filesystem without rebooting.
Which of the following commands will allow this to happen?

A Linux administrator is troubleshooting an issue with a shell script. Users in the accounting department are unable to run the script, but users in the sales department are not having issues. Users in both departments should be able to run the script. The administrator checks the permissions on the script and receives the following information:
-r-xr-xr-- joe sales script.sh
Which of the following commands should the administrator execute to resolve the problem?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
chmod a+x script.sh this is the answear you need 755 not 644...
C is correct. User home directory need execute permission in order to cd into it.
chmod 700 gives read write and execute. so why not A ?

comments.content:
Because you need x permission to /home/user02 but A will add x permission to:
chmod 700 /home/user02/.ssh
w/o adding +x to parent directory it will not work.
Proper answer C
